Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: A home loan repayment is due in two months, and the father needs to prepare for it
Situation2: They notice minor inconsistencies in a building plan that are unlikely to cause immediate issues.
Story:
I sat at my desk, the blueprints spread out before me, lines and numbers blurring together. As an architect, I knew the importance of precision—every detail mattered, especially when it came to safety and compliance. Today, I noticed a few minor inconsistencies in the building plan. They weren’t likely to cause immediate problems, but they nagged at me. Fixing them would mean more hours, more back-and-forth with the contractors, and possibly delaying the project.

But then, the weight of my other role pressed in. As a father, I was acutely aware that our home loan repayment was due in two months. My family depended on me for financial stability. If I delayed the project, I risked losing the client’s trust, maybe even the contract, and that bonus I was counting on to cover the loan.

My mind raced between the two worlds—my responsibility to my family and my duty as an architect. The expectations clashed inside me, each demanding my full attention. I stared at the plans, feeling the pressure build, knowing I had to choose which role to honor first.
